climbs.name: ZZZZZ Direct Start
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Todd Gordon, and Sara Matisse, Oct. 2012

content.description:
This is a 2-bolt direct start to ZZZZZ. Begin about 30 feet right of the normal start and climb up to and onto a dike (5.9), then tiptoe left to join ZZZZZ.

This start adds some quality moves to the pitch. I'd give ZZZZZ an extra star with the direct start (four stars instead of three).

Be forewarned that the direct start does not lesson the runnouts of the original route. Even though the direct start is well-protected, you still have to climb the runnout up to ZZZZZ's original first bolt (5.7 R) and the runnout from the first to the second bolt (5.8 PG) of the original route. Above this is a critical gear placement in a short crack (.75 inch, # .5 camalot) after which you can move up and right to a ledge with a 2-bolt anchor shared by Electric Blue/Blue Diamond/Electralux -or- move left and climb the face (5.8 PG) up to a big ledge and gear anchor. This is the line of the first ascent and gives you the full value pitch, although you'll need to set up a gear anchor and scramble off right (class 3) and descend slabs on the north side of the formation.
content.protection:
4 bolts, .75 inch CD,

gear anchor small to med.

climbs.name: ZZZZZ
climbs.fa: Randy Vogel, Charles Cole & Marjorie Shovlin, October 1983

content.description:
This fun face route is on excellent rock near the left side of the right end of the East Face of Little Hunk. It lies just left of

Electric Blue

(5.11c).

Begin off a boulder and head up and right on face, then straight up past 2 bolts to a small horizontal break (gear possible here). Finish up and left reaching a large ledge.

This route is a bit run out, but nothing that a calm head won't solve.
content.protection: Thin to 2 inches. 2 bolt anchor/rap or easy walk-off to right.

climbs.name: Unsolved Mystery
climbs.fa: unknown

content.description:
Closed to climbing due to the presence of nearby Native rock art; this route entry is for historical purposes only.

​​​​

Cool sculpted climbing through four bolts then a runout to a ledge and a crack to the top.

Can connect this to the second (better) half of Rad Nad or continue along the upper crack which is easy.
content.protection: Four bolts in the bottom standard rack for the top.
content.location: Left side of this wall, Rad Nad starts in a little gully to a bolt this is about 15 ft to the right.

climbs.name: TVC15
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Bruce Christle, October 1986

content.description: Begin just left of the start of Team Scumbag/Blues Traveler. Climb a left-slanting crack, move up to and climb a left-slanting dike, then climb past a flake up to the left end of a big ledge. Descend by walking off to the right (class 3).

climbs.name: Team Scumbag
climbs.fa: Alan Nelson and Bob Van Belle, November 1986

content.description:
Left of

ZZZZZ

(5.9 R) is this left-trending line on somewhat grainy rock. While the rock on this climb isn't on par with some of the others to the right, the moves are fun and well-protected. The route ends on a large ledge (the same ledge ZZZZZ finishes on), and an easy walk-off is found by walking northward down the toe of Little Hunk.

climbs.name: Smear Factor
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Tony Sartin, November 2002

content.description: Begin just right of Disrythmia and make some very delicate (12-) moves into a concavity, followed by overhanging jugs (11-).  The crux at the start is well-protected, and very balancey (like a V4 boulder problem). Once you solve this, you're into some steep face climbing on nice patina jugs.
content.protection: 6 bolts to 2 bolt anchor, 1 to 2 inch gear anchor for start.
content.location: Starts from the far left end of the big ramp on the extreme left side of Little Hunk's East face, about 50 feet up the ramp to the left of The New Deal.

climbs.name: Rad Nad
climbs.fa: (TR) Bob Gaines and Patty Kline, September, 2002, FL: Al Swanson, Steve Gerberding, Bill Serniuk, May 2006

content.description: A flaky start gains the first bolt and then climbs a lower angled lumpy face to a ledge. Above the ledge the wall steepens and fun moves past a huge patina flake conclude the pitch.
content.location:
Starts about 15 feet left of

Unsolved Mystery

.

climbs.name: Power Line
climbs.fa: Randy Vogel & Bob Dominick, August 1976

content.description: the start is pretty interesting...figure it out... I did it right off the ground no traverse as shown in Randys guide...personally for me it felt a little harder (Off route again most likely at the start...Just how I do things???...) than 5.7... whatever!!!... nice laybacking, solid holds, fun footwork... aiming at the bird doo doo, about 15 feet below it is a flake that is very likely to bust loose the very next time someone touches it... Belayer beware!!! Serious potential danger below!!! You can avoid it by moving left then getting back on route above it. The roof move is what some have said is the "Crux" move... The start was for me. The roof was just plain fun!!!
content.protection: protects well with nuts and cams in the small to medium range. Build an anchor... walk off...

climbs.name: Power Failure
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Frank Bentwood, May, 2008

content.description: Same start (5.8/9) as Power line and Power Drop. After about 15 feet move slightly right and climb the face (5.8) up to a horizontal crack. Above is a slightly overhanging face with 4 bolts and two 5.10+ sections.
content.protection:
CDs .3 to 1 inch. Two #00 metolious tcus (or black aliens) are very useful on the section below the first bolt.

Gear anchor: 3 to 4 inches.
content.location: You can walk on/off via the slabs to the northwest.

climbs.name: Power Drop
climbs.fa: Kevin Powell and Kevin Duck

content.description: This is a mixed crack and face, with shallow finger jams, liebacks, and an exposed traverse.  It's in a shady location.  This route is listed as "Power Lichen" in some guidebooks.
content.location: It starts below and right of Power Line, goes up to that route, then right and up.

climbs.name: Potato Head
climbs.fa: 1984 Dave Bruckman et al

content.description: Two obvious, vertical cracks will be seen on the Northeast face, right. Climb these cracks to the top. We TR'd this route, and I'm glad we did. The pro in the upper crack is PG with a runout. I suggest you TR it, and check it out before doing a lead. As I rapped it, I noted some problems setting pro in the crux area; and a fall there could be very serious indeed.

climbs.name: Police & Thieves
climbs.fa: Jordy Morgan and Chris Snyder, February 1988

content.description:
​​​​

Closed to climbing due to the presence of Native rock art; this route entry is for historical purposes only.

​​​​

Two bolts down low protect the fingery crux and then gear when available following a nebulous line that angles left to join Energy Crisis at the prominent horizontal crack about two thirds of the way up the face.
content.location:
Located 25 feet right of

Energy Crisis

.

climbs.name: New Deal
climbs.fa: Scott Cosgrove, 1988 (2nd ascent Alan Moore, 2010)

content.description: Rarely does a route look entirely impossible, but typical of Cosgrove's routes, this one does.  The climbing is very technical with miniscule slopers.  The first 15 feet are 5.13a, then 5.12c for 2 bolts, then if that isn't enough, after the 7th bolt 60' up comes the 5.13+ crux.  And just for some flavor, there is the Josh-typical 5.12a runout to the top.  Better be strong for this super endurance route.
content.location:
The middle of three bolted routes on the left face, a few hundred feet left of

ZZZZZ

.

climbs.name: Incandescent
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Patty Kline, March 2011

content.description: Start just right of Electralux and make a height dependent move (5.9 if you're 5 ft 10 or taller, harder if you're shorter) past a bolt up to a ledge, then climb a sustained slab (5.8-) on very high quality rock past 6 more bolts to a 2-bolt anchor (80 ft.)

climbs.name: Functional Analysis
climbs.fa: John Bachar & Mike Lechlinski 1983

content.description:
This is the right most crack line on this face.  Start with a hard face move to a left angling ramp feature.  Work up and left to a thin flared crack.

Please leave this route like the first ascencionist left it - a top rope.
content.location: Little Hunk north face on the far right side.

climbs.name: Flower Power
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines & Bruce Christle, October 1986

content.description: On the North East (right side) of Little Hunk, just right of a tree, are two, obvious, parallel, verical cracks. Climb the left crack until you can traverse left. Work the ledges left until you reach a crack leading to the top.

climbs.name: Energy Crisis
climbs.fa: Dean Fidelman, Guy Keesee and John Bald, February 1974

content.description:
Closed to climbing due to the presence of nearby Native rock art; this route entry is for historical purposes only.

​

Start in a shallow right facing corner and then follow discontinuous cracks past several horizontals through the patina covered face above. Gear belay and walk off.
content.location: The obvious crack splitting the patina between Unsolved Mystery and Police & Thieves.

climbs.name: Electric Blue
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, March 1988

content.description:
Expect delicate steep face climbing which culminates in a distinctive crux move near the 4th bolt as you grapple with the thinnest climbing on the route. Once past the crux the difficulties subside and it's easy to the top.

The great rock, well-protected and engaging moves and location all combine to make this a fun route for the grade. Three stars out of five.
content.location:
Located down and right from

ZZZZZ

and just left of a large flake leaning against the wall where

Blue Diamond (aka Shock to the System)

is located.

climbs.name: Electralux
climbs.fa: Yvonne Gaines and Bob Gaines, 1994

content.description:
Right of

Blue Diamond (aka Shock to the System)

is this left-trending slab route with engaging moves on quality rock that leads to shared anchors with Electric Blue and Blue Diamond. A fun route that's good on those warm days as well as being a nice place to escape the scene at Echo Rock.

climbs.name: Disrythmia
climbs.fa: Michael Paul, 1985

content.description: This  is a steep, 5 bolt face with a very thin crux.
content.protection: 5 bolts to 2 bolt anchor. 1 to 2 inch gear for anchor at base.
content.location:
This is the furthest left route on Little Hunk's East face, located by scrambling up the big chute/ramp past New Deal and Smear Factor. Begins just left of

Smear Factor

and goes straight up.

climbs.name: Direct Current
climbs.fa: John Long, Bob Gaines, and Eileen Descallar Ringwald, November 2020.

content.description: From the 3rd bolt on Electralux climb straight up, finishing left of and independent of Incandescent.
content.protection: Can be easily toproped from the Incandescent 2-bolt anchor.

climbs.name: Changes
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines & Tony Sartin, December 2003

content.description:
Begin from a gully about 50 ft. up and left from

Blues Traveller

(5.10d) and climb a low angle slab past 1 bolt (5.5) to a steep headwall (3 bolts, 11+) then easier (.9) steep face up and left past 5 more bolts to the top of the formation. 2 bolt rap. 100 ft.
content.protection:
9 bolts. 2 bolt rap anchor 100 ft.

A #1 camalot is useful before the 2nd bolt.

climbs.name: Cashews Will Be Eaten
climbs.fa: Randy Vogel, Charles Cole and Marjorie Shovlin, October 1983

content.description: per Miramontes: "Start up a flake/crack, then traverse right on a shelf, to a crack and face."
content.location: just L of Rad Nad (walk up the ramp ~ 30 ft)

climbs.name: Blues Traveler
climbs.fa: Chris Miller and Jim Hammerle, November 1995

content.description:
Start up

Team Scumbag

, clip the first bolt on that route, then continue straight up past three more bolts to anchors just below the top. The climbing is enjoyable and well-protected - yet another fun, moderate route to do when in the area.
content.protection: Gear to 1.5 inches, 4 bolts, anchors (all bolts 3/8")
content.location:
Located just left of

ZZZZZ

near the left margin of smooth rock that characterizes that climb.

climbs.name: Blue Diamond (aka Shock to the System)
climbs.fa: (TR) Bob Gaines, 1994; First Lead : Rex Pieper, 1994

content.description: Climb the outer face of the flake past a low bolt, then continue up the smooth face above the flake (crux) to shared anchors with Electric Blue. The lower portion of the route is on grainier rock while the upper portion is on high-quality stone.
content.location:
Right of

Electric Blue

is a large tan-colored flake resting against the main face, which is the start of this route.

climbs.name: Blue Cross
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, October 2003

content.description: From the second bolt of Team Scumbag climb up and right to the Blues Traveler anchor.
content.location: Same start as Team Scumbag/Blues Traveler.
